head.title: Having a Cool Car Is Becoming More Costly

hedline.hl1: Having a Cool Car Is Becoming More Costly

block.p: AS the weather grows warmer, more drivers will be rolling up their windows and turning on their air-conditioners. Some will be disappointed when nothing but accelerated warm air flows from the vents.
In the past, repairing an auto air-conditioner was often easy. A technician would pump in new refrigerant to replace any that leaked away in the winter, and check for leaks.
AS the weather grows warmer, more drivers will be rolling up their windows and turning on their air-conditioners. Some will be disappointed when nothing but accelerated warm air flows from the vents.
In the past, repairing an auto air-conditioner was often easy. A technician would pump in new refrigerant to replace any that leaked away in the winter, and check for leaks.

But tuning up an air-conditioner has become much more complicated, because of concern over depletion of the protective ozone layer in the atmosphere. The refrigerant used until recently in almost all car air-conditioners, R-12, is part of a class of chemicals, chlorofluorocarbons, that have been blamed for destroying the ozone layer. By international agreement, all chlorofluorocarbon production is to end by Dec. 31, 1995.

A new refrigerant, R-134a, has been developed that does not include chlorine and does not pose a threat to the ozone. Unfortunately, the two refrigerants are not compatible. If a car was designed to use R-12, R-134a cannot be substituted unless the system is modified. In fact, automotive engineers say, there are no "drop in" replacements for R-12.

The main reason for the incompatability, said Douglas E. Mark, an emissions engineer for the General Motors Corporation, is lubrication. In most cooling systems that use compressors, a lubricant is mixed with the refrigerant to reduce friction where mechanical parts rub together.
The problem is that mineral oil, the lubricant used with R-12, does not flow properly with R-134a. A different type of lubricant, polyalkylene glycol, is used with R-134a.

If R-134a is injected into a system designed for R-12, will the air-conditioner work? "Not for long," Mr. Mark said. "Without lubrication, the compressor would seize," shutting down the entire system.

Conversion to the new refrigerant was begun by most manufacturers about two years ago and will be completed by the end of this year. A label on the air-conditioner compressor will tell which refrigerant a car uses.

Owners of older cars must make some choices. Since production of R-12 has been declining, its price -- once as low as 88 cents a pound -- has been rising. (R-12 is also subject to a Federal tax.) Until recently, the bill for servicing an auto air-conditioner would be about $30, including the cost of labor and a few ounces of refrigerant.

But the cost of servicing a system has soared. "Last summer, the street price was about $100," Mr. Mark said. "It will be interesting to see what happens this summer." The cost is likely to be even higher next year.
Because of the ozone issue, Federal officials are pressuring car dealers and service shops not to simply refill leaky systems, but to detect the leaks and plug them.

Once production of R-12 ceases entirely next year, it will be available only from air-conditioning industry stockpiles and whatever is recovered from junked cars. That is why service specialists say it is important not to contaminate R-12 by adding another refrigerant like R-22, which is used in window air-conditioners. Once contaminated, R-12 cannot be recycled.
"People are coming into shops with R-22 in their systems, and flammable materials like propane and butane," said Simon Oulouhojian, president of the Mobile Air Conditioning Society Worldwide.

All auto manufacturers are developing conversion kits so that systems designed for R-12 can be modified to use R-134a. Some will be relatively simple, others more complicated and expensive. Nevertheless, as R-12 becomes more scarce and costly, auto executives say the conversions will increasingly become the more economical choice.

Mr. Oulouhojian said most conversion kits had not yet been developed; their prices are estimated at $200 to $800. He said costs were likely to be lower for newer cars with more modern cooling systems.

The cost of completely converting an older car may not make economic sense, he said. But there may be some alternatives, like a partial conversion. "If a customer is willing to accept air that is a few degrees hotter than in the past, the cost may be considerably lower," Mr. Oulouhojian said. DRIVING SMART
